identificationModule.briefTitle: Rehydration Efficiency During Ad-libitum Fluid Intake
identificationModule.officialTitle: Rehydration Efficiency During Ad-libitum Fluid Intake

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
It is well established that rehydration with a carbohydrate-electrolyte solution is more effective in comparison to plain water. This is primarily based on the sodium-glucose co transporter, based on which the world health organization has based its oral rehydration solution recommendations. Also, rehydration with a solution that includes sodium and glucose plasma osmolality should not drop as much as it happens during rehydration with water. As a result, we should have higher fluid intake due to higher thirst perception and lower urinary output due to higher levels of vasopressin.

The present study aims to examine the effectiveness of a electrolyte-glucose drink on rehydration following exercise-induced dehydration.

armGroups.label: Water
armGroups.description: Rehydration with low mineral content bottle water

armGroups.label: Carbohydrate Electrolyte solution
armGroups.description: Drink with 22 grams of carbohydrate, 1020 milligrams of sodium, and 760 milligrams of potassium per liter. Hydration multiplier liquid IV

armGroups.label: Low Sugar electrolyte solution
armGroups.description: 10 grams of carbohydrate, 1060 milligrams of sodium, and 760 milligrams of potassium per liter. Sugar free Liquid IV

interventions.name: Plain Water
interventions.description: Plain water without calories, sweetener, or electolytes

interventions.name: Liquid IV Hydration Multiplier
interventions.description: Drink with 22 grams of carbohydrate, 1020 milligrams of sodium, and 760 milligrams of potassium per liter. Hydration multiplier liquid IV

interventions.name: Liquid IV Sugar Free
interventions.description: 10 grams of carbohydrate, 1060 milligrams of sodium, and 760 milligrams of potassium per liter. Sugar free Liquid IV

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Age 18-60 years
* Training at least 2 times per week
* stable weight for the last 2 months (fluctuation less than 5 pounds)

Exclusion Criteria:

* Night shifting work
* Thyroid medication
* Bariatric surgery
* Cardiovascular disease
* Renal disease
* Hepatic disease
* Participating in another study at the same time
* Bodyweight over 110 pounds
